structured_info.title_cn: 面向交通信息物理系统的智能区块链认证协议
structured_info.title_en: An Intelligent Blockchain-Enabled Authentication Protocol for Transportation Cyber-Physical Systems
structured_info.abstract: Transportation Cyber-Physical System (T-CPS) integrates physical transportation infrastructure with network technology and computational algorithms to enable real-time monitoring, traffic forecasting, and efficient management. However, public channel data transmission exposes T-CPS to security threats. This paper proposes a blockchain-based lightweight authentication protocol to enhance security and trustworthiness in Intelligent Transportation Systems. The protocol resists common attacks like capture and insider attacks, validated through Real-Or-Random model proofs. Efficiency evaluations confirm its lightweight nature and robustness, advancing secure communication for autonomous driving and traffic management applications.
structured_info.methodology: Proposes a blockchain-based authentication protocol using elliptic curve cryptography, hash functions, and smart contracts. Employs multi-Trust Authority management in a private blockchain with Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance consensus. Includes five phases: initialization, registration, login/authentication, block construction/verification, and vehicle revocation. Security is formally verified via Real-Or-Random model.
structured_info.conclusion: The protocol achieves mutual authentication, anonymity, perfect forward secrecy, and resistance to replay/impersonation attacks. It reduces computational overhead (5.0626 ms) and communication costs (2944 bits) versus existing methods while enabling efficient vehicle revocation. Blockchain integration mitigates single-point failures and enhances data integrity for vehicular networks.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: Proposes a lightweight blockchain-based authentication protocol for securing vehicle-to-infrastructure communication in Transportation Cyber-Physical Systems, addressing security vulnerabilities while optimizing computational efficiency.
Background_and_Motivation: T-CPS faces security risks from wireless data transmission (e.g., data leaks like the 2022 NIO incident) and single-point failures in centralized Trusted Authorities.
To solve vulnerabilities to eavesdropping, impersonation, and physical capture attacks while ensuring anonymity and scalability.
Emphasizes urgency via real-world data breach incidents and the critical need for secure autonomous vehicle communication.
Links vehicular security to broader challenges in intelligent infrastructure, highlighting risks of traffic accidents and system failures from compromised data.
Cybersecurity, Blockchain Applications, and Intelligent Transportation Systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Intelligent Blockchain: Private blockchain with smart contracts for decentralized authentication and automated threat response
Pseudo-Identity (R_ID): Dynamic identity masking real vehicle IDs using hash functions
Session Key (SK): Ephemeral key derived from elliptic curve parameters for secure communication
Blockchain stores pseudo-identities and keys; smart contracts verify blocks during authentication; session keys enable encrypted communication between vehicles and authorities.
Trusted Authorities are fully trusted; adversaries cannot simultaneously compromise master keys and shared vehicle keys; roadside units operate in semi-trusted environments.
Novel framework integrating blockchain with lightweight cryptography, advancing decentralized trust models in vehicular networks.
Methodology: Uses elliptic curve cryptography for key generation, hash functions for integrity, and PBFT consensus for blockchain validation. Smart contracts automate block verification.
Novelty: First integration of multi-TA management with blockchain in T-CPS. Applicable to high-mobility scenarios; rational through formal ROR security proofs.
Simulated using OnePlus AcePro (vehicle node), Lenovo desktop (RSU), and Huawei laptop (TA). No real-world data; cryptographic operations benchmarked 10 times for average execution metrics.
Formal security verification via ROR model; evaluation metrics include computation/communication costs and attack resistance. Lacks real-world penetration testing.
Follows cryptographic protocol design paradigm, focusing on provable security—constrains analysis to theoretical adversarial models.
Results: Computational cost: 5.0626 ms (lower than comparable protocols). Communication cost: 2944 bits (lowest among evaluated schemes). Resists 9 attack types including replay and impersonation.
Results are statistically stable (10-test average) but reliability untested in real-world deployments. Significance lies in balanced security-efficiency trade-off.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structured as: (1) Problem identification → (2) Protocol design → (3) Security proofs → (4) Performance benchmarking → (5) Comparative validation.
Key steps: Security vulnerabilities motivate blockchain integration; ROR proofs establish theoretical robustness; cost comparisons demonstrate efficiency.
Strengths: Comprehensive formal/informal security analysis. Weakness: Scalability limits in blockchain consensus under high vehicle density. Rebuttals: Future work will address scalability.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Innovations: Lightweight design, vehicle revocation mechanism, and PBFT-based blockchain. Outperforms prior work in communication cost and attack coverage.
Untested in large-scale deployments; PBFT consensus may bottleneck scalability. Assumes semi-trusted RSUs—malicious RSUs not fully explored.
Cryptographic paradigm prioritizes theoretical security over real-world adaptability, limiting insights into physical-layer vulnerabilities.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions as a bridge between blockchain and vehicular security literature, addressing limitations in certificate-based schemes.
Technical terminology (e.g., 'ROR model', 'pseudo-identity'); persuasive tone emphasizing urgency via breach examples; contrasts prior work in Table I to highlight gaps.
Builds authority through 44 citations (e.g., Raya and Hubaux, Lu et al.). Motivations include countering certificate revocation flaws and single-TA inefficiencies.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Protocol achieves secure, efficient authentication with anonymity and forward secrecy. Blockchain integration mitigates centralized risks.
Future work: Optimize PBFT for scalability; test in real-world IoV environments; explore post-quantum cryptographic integration.
